department_info.chairperson_message: Chairperson's Message Dr. Maheen Islam Faculty of Sciences and Engineering Chairperson & Associate Professor Department of Computer Science and Engineering We welcome you on behalf of the faculty, staff, and students of the Department of Computer Science and Engineering (CSE) at the East West University (EWU).. It is one of the few private universities in Bangladesh that has got a Permanent Certificate from the Ministry of Education by fulfilling all the criteria set for the status. Read More

curriculum.Graduates will establish themselves as l: Graduates will engage themselves in lifelong pursuit of knowledge and interdisciplinary learning for industrial, research, and academic careers and/or leadership and entrepreneurship development.

Graduates will contribute to sustainable development and the well-being of the society through the use of Computer Science and Engineering principles, practices and tools in an ethical and responsible manner.

curriculum.Description: Apply knowledge of mathematics, natural sciences, engineering fundamentals and an engineering specialization as specified in K1 to K4 respectively to the solution of complex computer science and engineering problems (EP1 to EP7).

Identify, formulate, research literature and analyze complex computer science and engineering problems (EP1 to EP7) reaching substantiated conclusions using first principles of mathematics, natural sciences and engineering sciences. (K1 to K4)

Design solutions for complex computer science and engineering problems (EP1 to EP7) and design systems, components or processes that meet specified needs with appropriate consideration for public health and safety, cultural, societal, and environmental considerations. (K5)

Conduct investigations of complex computer science and engineering problems (EP1 to EP7) using research-based knowledge (K8) and research methods including design of experiments, analysis and interpretation of data, and synthesis of information to provide valid conclusions.

Create, select and apply appropriate techniques, resources, and modern engineering and IT tools, including prediction and modeling, to complex computer science and engineering problems (EP1 to EP7), with an understanding of the limitations. (K6)

Apply reasoning informed by contextual knowledge to assess societal, health, safety, legal and cultural issues and the consequent responsibilities relevant to professional computer science and engineering practice and solutions to complex computer science and engineering problems (EP1 to EP7). (K7)

Understand and evaluate the sustainability and impact of professional computer science and engineering work in the solution of complex computer science and engineering problems (EP1 to EP7) in societal and environmental contexts. (K7)
Apply ethical principles and commit to professional ethics and responsibilities and norms of computer science and engineering practice. (K7)
Function effectively as an individual, and as a member or leader in diverse teams and in multi-disciplinary settings.

Communicate effectively on complex computer science and engineering activities (EA1 to EA5) with the computer science and engineering community and with society at large, such as being able to comprehend and write effective reports and design documentation, make effective presentations, and give and receive clear instructions.

Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of engineering management principles and economic decision-making and apply these to one’s own work, as a member and leader in a team, to manage projects and in multidisciplinary environments.
Recognize the need for, and have the preparation and ability to engage in independent and life-long learning in the broadest context of technological change.

curriculum.Attribute: A systematic, theory-based understanding of the natural sciences applicable to the discipline

curriculum.Knowledge Profile: K2: Conceptually-based mathematics, numerical analysis, statistics, and formal aspects of computer and information science
curriculum.Attribute: Conceptually based mathematics, numerical analysis, statistics and the formal aspects of computer and information science to support analysis and modeling applicable to the discipline
A systematic, theory-based formulation of engineering fundamentals required in the engineering discipline

curriculum.Knowledge Profile: K4: Forefront engineering specialist knowledge for practice
curriculum.Attribute: Engineering specialist knowledge that provides theoretical frameworks and bodies of knowledge for the accepted practice areas in the engineering discipline; much is at the forefront of the discipline
Knowledge that supports engineering design in a practice area
Knowledge of engineering practice (technology) in the practice areas in the engineering discipline

curriculum.Knowledge Profile: K7: Comprehension of engineering in society
curriculum.Attribute: Comprehension of the role of engineering in society and identified issues in engineering practice in the discipline: ethics and the engineer’s professional responsibility to public safety; the impacts of engineering activity; economic, social, cultural, environmental and sustainability
Engagement with selected knowledge in the research literature of the discipline
EP1: Depth of knowledge required
curriculum.Characteristics of Complex Engineering P: Cannot be resolved without in-depth engineering knowledge at the level of one or more of K3, K4, K5, K6, or K8 which allows a fundamental-based, first principles analytical approach

curriculum.Attribute: EP2: Range of conflicting requirements
curriculum.Characteristics of Complex Engineering P: Involve wide-ranging or conflicting technical, engineering and other issues

curriculum.Attribute: EP3: Depth of analysis required
curriculum.Characteristics of Complex Engineering P: Have no obvious solution and require abstract thinking, originality in analysis to formulate suitable models

curriculum.Attribute: EP4: Familiarity of issues
EP5: Extent of applicable codes
curriculum.Characteristics of Complex Engineering P: Are outside problems encompassed by standards and codes of practice for professional engineering

curriculum.Attribute: EP 6: Extent of stakeholder involvement and conflicting requirements
curriculum.Characteristics of Complex Engineering P: Involve diverse groups of stakeholders with widely varying needs

curriculum.Attribute: EP7: Interdependence
curriculum.Characteristics of Complex Engineering P: Are high level problems including many component parts or sub-problems

curriculum.Attribute: EA1: Range of resources
curriculum.Characteristics of Complex Engineering A: Involve the use of diverse resources (for this purpose, resources include people, money, equipment, materials, information and technologies)

curriculum.Attribute: EA2: Level of interaction
curriculum.Characteristics of Complex Engineering A: Require resolution of significant problems arising from interactions between wide-ranging or conflicting technical, engineering or other issues

curriculum.Attribute: EA3: Innovation
curriculum.Characteristics of Complex Engineering A: Involve creative use of engineering principles and research-based knowledge in novel ways

curriculum.Attribute: EA4: Consequences for society and the environment
curriculum.Characteristics of Complex Engineering A: Have significant consequences in a range of contexts, characterized by difficulty of prediction and mitigation

curriculum.Attribute: EA5: Familiarity
curriculum.Characteristics of Complex Engineering A: Can extend beyond previous experiences by applying principle-based approaches

curriculum.Course Category: Compulsory Language and General Education Courses
Core Computer Science and Engineering Courses
Major Compulsory and Elective Computer Science and Engineering Courses
Non-major Elective Computer Science and Engineering Courses

curriculum.Course: Compulsory Language and General Education Courses
SOC317 Sociology of Science and Technology
Arts and Humanities Courses (any one course)
SOC217 Religion, Ethnicity, Culture and Development in South Asia
BUS321 Business for Engineering and Technology
MAT102 Differential Equations and Special Functions
MAT104 Coordinate Geometry and Vector Analysis
MAT205 Linear Algebra and Complex Variable
Core Computer Science and Engineering Courses
CSE347 Information System Analysis and Design
CSE487 Cyber Security, Ethics and Law
CSE495 IT Project Management and Entrepreneurship

curriculum.Credits: Courses from the selected major area

curriculum.Course: Student should select one of the four major areas for degree major requirement
Minimum 8 credits ( two to three courses depending on credits of the courses) from one or more major/non-major areas other than the selected major area
Four Major Areas and Courses (2 Compulsory and 3 Elective Courses)
CSE430 Software Testing and Quality Assurance
CSE472 Advanced Network Services and Management

curriculum: MAT102 Differential Equations and Special Functions (3)
curriculum.2nd Year: MAT205 Linear Algebra and Complex Variables (3)
curriculum.4th Year: CSE347 Information System Analysis and Design (3+1=4)

curriculum: MAT104 Coordinate Geometry and Vector Analysis (3)
